pageData.text: This investigation is designed to give students the tools they need to identify minerals in the field. Students will classify minerals by conducting selected physical and chemical diagnostic tests described in this activity.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – Variable 
Activity 1: Identifying Properties of Minerals – 2 hours

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: 10 or more mineral specimens
Camera or cell phone capable of taking photographs
Timer
Define and compare rocks and minerals.
Characterize mineral samples using a number of chemical and physical tests.
Define <button class='glossary-text'>luster</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>opacity</button>.
Distinguish between <button class='glossary-text'>cleavage</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.subTitle: Protocol symbols
pageData.altText: video link symbol, camera symbol, stopwatch symbol

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol, flammable symbol, toxic symbol, environment symbol, health hazard symbol

pageData.text: Many of the developments that have allowed smartphones to become commonplace rely on minerals. For instance, the touchscreen of most phones has a glass display primarily made of silica, with sphalerite-derived indium and germanium making up the conductive "touch" LED display. As phones have gotten thinner, inks containing silver (derived from tetrahedrite) are used to print the connections for incredibly thin silicon (found in quartz) circuits.  Similarly, new and improved batteries with longer life and faster charging rates are made from lithium (found in spodumene) and graphite<sup>1</sup>.

All these minerals are finite resources and must be extracted from the earth through mining, which exacts an enormous environmental toll. Many companies and organizations are working on ways to better recycle the minerals within old smart phones to reduce the need for continual mineral extraction.

1Jenness, J. E., Ober, J. A., Wilkins, A. M., & Gambogi, J. (2016, September 15). A world of minerals in your mobile device. United States Geological Survey.
https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/gip167

pageData.altText: A smartphone propped up by rocks on a sandy area.

pageData.text: Minerals are solid, inorganic, (same all the way through) substances with a definite chemical composition and structure. The terms rock and mineral are sometimes used interchangeably, but a rock is a (nonuniform) combination of minerals. For example, granite is a rock that contains a mixture of the minerals mica, feldspar, and quartz (see Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A piece of granite

pageData.text: The easiest way to identify minerals in the field is to describe their physical and chemical characteristics and then to use the description in conjunction with a field guide on minerals.The main characteristics used by geologists to identify a mineral are <button class='glossary-text'>color</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>luster</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>streak</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cleavage</button> versus <button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button>. There are additional characteristics that are specific to only a few minerals and can assist in identification. These characteristics include magnetism, taste, and release of CO<sub>2</sub> gas in the presence of an acid.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A rock is a coherent, naturally occurring solid consisting of an aggregate of minerals, pieces of pre-existing rocks, volcanic glass, or even a mass of organic material.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about minerals or rock is true?

options.text: Minerals are homogenous while rocks are heterogeneous.
Rocks always contain more than one mineral.
Rocks and minerals are organic substances found in the earth.
Rocks and minerals are both aggregates of inorganic materials.
Minerals have a random internal structure.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Minerals are solid, inorganic, homogeneous (same all the way through) substances with a definite chemical composition and structure. Rock is a heterogeneous (nonuniform) combination of minerals.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In the earth, most minerals are found as parts of rock. It is important to know the difference between a mineral specimen and a rock. Some rocks, like granite, contain grains of several different minerals; and some, like rock salt, are made of many grains of a single mineral. Others are made of fragments of previously existing rock that are cemented together or from volcanic glass that cooled so quickly from a molten state that their atoms did not have time to form the internal grid-like crystalline structure found in minerals. Granite, an example of rock, is an aggregate of several common rock-forming minerals, including biotite mica (black), plagioclase feldspar (gray or white), quartz (clear or white), and potassium feldspar (pink). Minerals are solid, inorganic, homogeneous substances with a definite chemical composition and structure.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In the earth, most minerals are found as parts of rock. It is important to know the difference between a mineral specimen and a rock. Some rocks, like granite, contain grains of several different minerals; and some, like rock salt, are made of many grains of a single mineral. Others are made of fragments of previously existing rock that are cemented together or from volcanic glass that cooled so quickly from a molten state that their atoms did not have time to form the internal grid-like crystalline structure found in minerals. Granite, an example of rock, is an aggregate of several common rock-forming minerals, including biotite mica (black), plagioclase feldspar (gray or white), quartz (clear or white), and potassium feldspar (pink). Minerals are solid, inorganic, homogeneous substances with a definite chemical composition and structure.

pageData.subTitle: Color
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Color</button> may be a mineral’s most obvious characteristic, yet it is often unreliable for identifying a mineral. For example, the common mineral quartz may be clear, smoky gray, pink, yellow, brown, purple (known as amethyst), or milky white. Variations in the color of minerals comes from several sources.

One common source of color variation under natural conditions is the presence of metal ions in the crystal. Some metal ions have multiple oxidation states (number of electrons that the atom can share), and the change from one oxidation state to another can cause color changes. Another source of color variation is natural irradiation.

Color variations in the mineral beryl result from all these processes. Many gemstones used by jewelers are variants of the beryl crystal. Pure beryl is composed of the elements beryllium, aluminum, silicon, and oxygen. When it is pure, beryl is a clear crystal called goshenite. Trace amounts of chromium will cause beryl to be green. This variety is known as the gemstone emerald. The presence of manganese (II) (Mn<sup>2+</sup>) results in pink morganite. The presence of manganese (III) (Mn<sup>3+</sup>) will produce a much darker red, which is called red beryl. Golden beryl has impurities of iron (III) (Fe<sup>3+</sup>). If small amounts of iron (II) (Fe<sup>2+</sup>) are present, the crystal is pale blue and is known as the gemstone aquamarine. The blue/green color of some aquamarines is due to intervalence charge transfer between Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup> (the two iron species gain and loose electrons to each other). Another beryl variety, maxixe, has a dark sapphire-like blue color that is caused in part by the presence of both iron species. The color is produced by natural irradiation and is unstable.

Natural irradiation can occur when the mineral is near a source of gamma radiation, such as uranium ore. The radiation dose required to change the color is quite large, but the radiation source does not have to be strong because radiation accumulates over geological time scales. Exposing the irradiated crystal to heat or sunlight releases the electrons and causes the color to fade in some minerals, whereas heat or sunlight will fix the colors in other crystals. Many gemstones are artificially irradiated or heat-treated to intensify color (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A gemstone that has been artificially irradiated to intensify its color

pageData.text: Diffraction also can cause opalescent colors (varying colors that can be seen in an opal) in some gems. Some sulfides and other semiconductors display intense colors, which are due to band gaps created by electron excitation by light followed by a return to their original energy state.

pageData.subTitle: Hardness
pageData.text: is a mineral’s resistance to being scratched. This is different from , which is the mineral’s resistance to breaking, crushing, bending, or tearing. Mineral hardness is determined by comparing a mineral to other materials that have a known hardness. In 1822, the German mineralogist Friedrich Mohs published a relative hardness scale. This scale is a comparative ranking of the hardness of common abundant minerals. Minerals with greater hardness have higher numbers. To perform a hardness test, a mineral is scratched with minerals of a defined hardness. If the known mineral fails to scratch the test mineral, then the test mineral has greater hardness than the known mineral.

The Mohs hardness scale is a purely ordinal scale, which ranks minerals according to their relative hardness and assigns a number without units (see Table 1). A Turner’s sclerometer can be used to determine absolute hardness, which is the amount of pressure in grams that is required to create a standard scratch on the unknown mineral (see Table 1). The hardness scale transition between talc (Mohs hardness = 1) and gypsum (Mohs hardness = 2) on the Mohs scale is equivalent to a three-fold increase in absolute hardness. However, the 1-point increase on the Mohs scale between topaz (Mohs hardness = 8) and corundum (Mohs hardness = 9) is equivalent to a 200-fold increase in absolute hardness. Despite the limitations of the Mohs scale, it continues to be used because of its history and because it is an easy test to perform, especially under field conditions.

Not all of these minerals are readily available during field investigations. Therefore, the Mohs hardness of common items like glass (5.5), a nail (4), a penny (3), and a fingernail (2.5) was determined. These common items can be used to scratch an unknown mineral and determine its relative hardness.

When testing mineral <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button>, it is important to use a fresh surface of the mineral that has not been affected by weathering. In some cases, it is easier to draw the unknown mineral across the known material (for example, scraping the mineral across a glass plate). In other cases, it is easier to draw the known material across the unknown mineral (for example, scratching the mineral with your fingernail). It is important not to confuse a scratch on the mineral surface with a powder mark. A true scratch cannot be wiped away or rubbed off.

pageData.subTitle: Luster
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Luster</button> is the sheen, or gloss, of the mineral surface. The two major types of luster are <button class='glossary-text'>metallic</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>nonmetallic</button>. Metallic minerals have a sheen similar to that of metal and are reflective. They usually are opaque, and their <button class='glossary-text'>streak</button> tends to be dark (see the information in the “Streak” section). Hematite is an example of a mineral with a metallic luster. Nearly opaque minerals with a metallic sheen are called <button class='glossary-text'>submetallic</button>. Nonmetallic lusters can have a variety of sheens. Most gemstones are either <button class='glossary-text'>vitreous</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>adamantine</button>. Vitreous minerals, such as quartz, have a luster similar to glass. Diamonds display brilliance because a high refractive index causes light to reflect off multiple surfaces within the mineral. Minerals that display this quality are said to be adamantine. Minerals with a <button class='glossary-text'>pearly</button> luster display iridescence. <button class='glossary-text'>Greasy</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>waxy</button> minerals look like they are coated with a layer of grease or wax, whereas parallel <button class='glossary-text'>fibrous</button> crystals create a <button class='glossary-text'>silky</button> luster. <button class='glossary-text'>Resinous</button> minerals resemble honey or amber in their luster. Minerals that have very little shine are known as <button class='glossary-text'>dull</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Opacity
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Opacity</button> describes how much light can be seen through a thin slice of a mineral. There are three primary descriptors for opacity (see Figure 3).

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A blue square over a pink circle demonstrates each descriptor of opacity. The top square over a circle is opaque, allowing no light to show through the square; the middle is translucent, with only the shape of the circle visible; and the bottom is transparent, with light showing through and the image of the circle visible.

pageData.text: Opacity can vary greatly depending on the levels of flaws, inclusions, and impurities in the mineral.

pageData.subTitle: Streak
pageData.text: is the of a mineral when it is finely powdered. Although the color of a mineral may vary, its streak is usually constant. A mineral streak can be obtained by scratching the mineral against a piece of unglazed porcelain, such as the streak plates included in your materials kit. A colored streak is an important physical property, especially for minerals with a . White or clear streaks are less useful for identification. Minerals with a greater than seven cannot be tested on the streak plate—the hardness is too great, and the minerals will not leave a residue.

pageData.subTitle: Cleavage Versus Fracture
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cleavage</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button> are different ways to describe how a mineral breaks. Sometimes weathering of the mineral obscures these features. In such cases, the mineral can be struck with a rock hammer to expose a fresh surface.

A mineral possessing cleavage breaks along definite planes that are parallel to the atomic planes of the crystal, thereby creating flat surfaces. Cleavage surfaces often reflect light well and appear as a single bright flash when rotated in light. Cleavage can occur in one, two, or three directions. Halite, or table salt, is a good example of cleavage in three directions. No matter how small a grain of salt is, it will always break into a perfect cube. All three directions have flat cleavage planes (see ). Mica shows cleavage in only one direction, as exhibited by thin sheets that can easily be pulled apart.

tableData.hoverText: A sketch of quartz as an amorphous rounded shape.
A sketch of muscovite as three stacked flat sheets.
A sketch of a horizontal plane.

tableData.text:
2 directions at 90°
Elongated with rectangle cross section (prism)
tableData.hoverText:
2 directions at 90° 
Elongated with rectangle cross section (prism)
A sketch of feldspar as a rectangular prism shape.
A sketch of two perpendicular planes joined at their midlines.
A sketch of halite as several conjoined cubes of various sizes.
A sketch of three planes running along the x, y, and z axes.
A sketch of calcite as a rhomohedron shape.
A sketch of three planes running along the x, y, and z axes, with each plane slanted at the same angle.

pageData.text: If a mineral does not break into flat planes but instead breaks irregularly, it is said to <button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button>. Fracture surfaces tend to be rough and do not reflect light as well as <button class='glossary-text'>cleavage</button> surfaces. Fracture is characterized as <button class='glossary-text'>conchoidal</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>fibrous</button>/<button class='glossary-text'>splintery</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>irregular</button>. Conchoidal fractures are smooth and curved. Breaking glass exhibits conchoidal fracture. Fibrous or splintery fractures are jagged and sharp. Uneven or irregular fractures produce a rough surface. A good example of a mineral that exhibits irregular fracture is quartz. Quartz crystals grow with flat surfaces that could appear to be cleavage faces; however, if the crystal is broken, the remaining surface exhibits irregular fracture. Crystal growth habit and cleavage properties are based on the underlying atomic structure, but growth habit also is determined by local environmental conditions at the time of growth.
Some minerals exhibit both cleavage and fracture. They may break along a cleavage plane in one direction and fracture unevenly in another.

pageData.question: Which of the following factors is responsible for the way a mineral breaks?

options.text: the bonds in its internal structure
if it is an irregular-shaped mass
the type of tool used to break it

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The way in which a mineral breaks (cleaves) is controlled by whether there are zones of weak bonds in its internal crystalline structure.

pageData.question: Minerals tend to cleave along which of the following surfaces?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Cleavage is the tendency of some minerals to break (cleave) along flat, parallel surfaces.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: If you took a box of mineral samples and broke them with a hammer or dropped them on the floor so that they shattered into smaller pieces, you would notice that minerals break in a variety of ways. Some break along smooth planes, others along curved surfaces, and still others in irregular shapes.  You can examine specimens to see how they have already broken using a magnifying glass to see more clearly. Cleavage is the tendency of some minerals to break (cleave) along flat, parallel surfaces. Cleavage occurs when chemical bonds holding atoms together are weaker in some directions than others. The mineral breaks along these zones of weakness, producing flat, smooth surfaces. Each set of parallel cleavage planes is referred to as a cleavage direction. Minerals can have more than one direction of cleavage. If there is more than one zone of weakness, the mineral cleaves in more than one direction. So, it is always important to note how many directions there are and the angles between those directions when describing a mineral’s cleavage. To observe a mineral’s cleavage, hold it up to the light and slowly rotate it. Parallel cleavage surfaces will reflect light at the same time, making different cleavage directions easier to see.

If there is more than one zone of weakness, the mineral cleaves in more than one direction. So, it is always important to note how many directions there are and the angles between those directions when describing a mineral’s cleavage. To observe a mineral’s cleavage, hold it up to the light and slowly rotate it. Parallel cleavage surfaces will reflect light at the same time, making different cleavage directions easier to see.

pageData.subTitle: Specific Gravity
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Specific gravity</button> refers to the weight of a mineral compared with the weight of an equal volume of water. Specific gravity is indicated numerically; water, for example, has a specific gravity of one. A mineral with a specific gravity of two is twice as dense as water. Most minerals have a specific gravity of between 2.5 and 2.8. Gold has the highest specific gravity of 19. For the purposes of field identification, note whether a mineral feels particularly light or heavy. Quartz is a good comparative reference; it has a specific gravity of 2.65.

pageData.subTitle: Other Properties
pageData.text: Some properties are unique to certain minerals. Taste may be useful in identifying some water-soluble minerals. Water-soluble minerals will dissolve in the perspiration from your fingers. Halite is used as table salt and tastes salty. Tasting minerals is strongly discouraged for those who are inexperienced because many minerals contain toxic elements and metals.

Magnetism is another unique diagnostic property for identifying an unknown mineral. Only three minerals exhibit enough magnetism to be detected in a simple test using a magnet. Magnetite is strongly magnetic, whereas pyrrhotite and ilmenite are less strongly magnetic.

Some minerals in the carbonate family are soluble (dissolve) in acid. The mineral calcite reacts with acid. When a drop of acid is placed on the surface of calcite, CO<sub>2</sub> released from the mineral forms bubbles in the drop. Dolomite also reacts in the presence of acid but not as vigorously as calcite.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will obtain and photograph your mineral samples. In activity 1, you will observe the luster and color of the mineral. Then, you will test the streak of the mineral. You will test the streaks in the following order, fingernail on the mineral, penny on the mineral, mineral on glass plate and mineral on streak plate. Once you have a positive streak, do not try the next material, but instead go on to photograph the streak. If it is negative, keep trying the different tests until you get a positive result. If the mineral does not streak the streak plate, record this and go on to observe the cleavage and fracture of the mineral. Next, you will add acid to the mineral and observe for changes. Then, you will test the magnetism of the mineral. Finally, you will classify each mineral according to its properties.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
Hydrochloric acid is a corrosive material. Use this near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Hydrochloric acid is toxic if inhaled.
pageData.altText: toxic symbol

pageData.text: Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: When each is scratched with a metal nail, Mineral A is left with a mark while Mineral B shows no marks. Which of the following statements is true about Minerals A and B?

options.text: Mineral A has a smaller hardness value than Mineral B.
Mineral A has a smaller tenacity value than Mineral B.
Mineral A has a metallic luster while Mineral B has a nonmetallic luster.
Mineral A has more streak than Mineral B.
Mineral A is likely to cleave while Mineral B is likely to fracture.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a type of nonmetallic luster?
A thin slice of an unknown mineral allows some light to pass through it, although not enough to make out any text held behind it. Which of the following best describes the minerals opacity?
A mineral that cleaves in 3 directions will form which of the following shapes?
Which of the following statements is true of a mineral with a specific gravity of 3.0?

options.text: The mineral is three times heavier than water.
The mineral is denser than diamond.
The mineral is less dense than most minerals.
The mineral can be cleaved in 3 directions.
The mineral will not fracture when dropped on the ground.

assestmentData.question: What safety hazard is associated with hydrochloric acid, which will be used in this investigation?

options.text: It is extremely toxic to aquatic wildlife.

assestmentData.question: How many mineral samples will you need to collect in order to complete the investigation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.

Collect samples according to your instructor’s directions, or use mineral samples provided in a supplied mineral set. If you are collecting your own samples, collect at least 10 specimens because several are likely to be too impure for accurate analysis. Take photographs of the minerals you will be using.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will test unknown mineral samples for <button class='glossary-text'>luster</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>color</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>streak</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>cleavage</button>/<button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button> and special properties. You will then determine the name of each mineral based on its properties.

pages.title: Identifying Properties of Minerals (7 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Identifying Properties of Minerals (7 steps)

pageData.text: Determine the mineral’s as (M) or (NM). Record the luster in Data Table 1.

text: A metallic mineral is opaque and looks similar to metal.

A nonmetallic mineral does not look like metal; instead, it has a glossy reflection or is <button class='glossary-text'>waxy</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>pearly</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>dull</button>/earthy.

pageData.text: Determine the mineral’s . Record and describe it in Data Table 1.

Determine the <button class='glossary-text'>streak</button> of the mineral by performing the streak test. Use the white streak plate for a darker-colored mineral and the black streak plate for a lighter-colored mineral.

text: Firmly drag the sample to be tested across one of the streak plates.
If color can be distinguished, record the color in Data Table 1 in the streak column. If no color is left behind, try testing the sample on the opposite-colored streak plate.
If no color is left behind on either streak plate but the streak plates are scratched, record “not applicable” (N/A) in the mineral’s streak box.

pageData.text: Determine the mineral’s relative <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button> range.

text: Locate a smooth surface on the mineral.
Hold the sample firmly against a solid surface, like a table.
With your other hand, firmly press the edge of your fingernail against the sample and drag it across the surface of the mineral. (This test may be inaccurate if your nails are painted or acrylic.)

Gently brush the surface to remove any residue from the nail that may have been left behind.
  • If there is a scratch on the sample, the mineral has a hardness of ≤ 2.5. Proceed to Step 4i.
  • If there is no scratch on the sample, then proceed to Step 4e.

Repeat Steps 4a–4d using the edge of a penny.
  • If there is a scratch on the sample, the mineral has a hardness > 2.5 and ≤ 3. Proceed to Step 4i.
  • If there is no scratch on the sample, then proceed to Step 4f.

Repeat Steps 4a–4d using the end of a nail.
  • If there is a scratch on the sample, the mineral has a hardness > 3 and ≤ 5. Proceed to Step 4i.
  • If there is no scratch on the sample, then proceed to Step 4g.

Firmly hold the glass plate down on a flat surface, like a table, with the index finger and thumb of your nondominant hand. Then grip the sample in your dominant hand, and slide the mineral across the glass plate.
  • If there is a scratch on the glass plate, the mineral has a hardness of > 5 and ≤ 5.5. Proceed to Step 4i.
  • If there is no scratch on the glass plate, then proceed to Step 4h.

Firmly hold the white streak plate on a flat surface, like a table, with the index finger and thumb of your nondominant hand. Then grip the sample in your dominant hand, and slide it across the streak plate.
  • If there is a scratch on the streak plate, the mineral’s hardness is > 5.5 and ≤ 7. Proceed to Step 4i.
  • If there is no scratch on the streak plate, the mineral has a hardness of > 7. Proceed to Step 4i.

pageData.text: Record your results in Data Table 1, and take a photograph of each mineral next to the item that made a streak on it.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Determine the mineral’s (if present) or (if present). Use the hand lens to observe each mineral more closely. For cleavage, determine the number of cleavage directions and the angle they meet (at 90° or not at 90°) or the name (example, cubic), if possible. For minerals that display fractures, specify as , , or , if possible. Record the information in Data Table 1.
Determine whether or not each mineral displays any of the following special properties.
Note: Wear your safety goggles, lab apron, and gloves while using the hydrochloric acid. The acid test should be performed only in an area with easy access to a shower or eyewash.

Does the mineral react with acid? Place the mineral sample on top of several layers of paper towels. Add several drops of hydrochloric acid to each mineral sample, and wait several minutes. Look (using the hand lens if needed) and listen for any evidence of bubbles, indicating a reaction. Record your observation in Data Table 1. Samples with a high level of calcite or aragonite will bubble vigorously. Other carbonate minerals will have a weaker reaction, and it may take a few minutes for bubbles to appear on the surface of the acid drop. Continue to observe your samples for at least 5 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Does the mineral display magnetic attraction (strongly or weakly)? Hold the magnet a few millimeters from the surface of the mineral. Record in Data Table 1 if the mineral is attracted to the magnet and if the attraction feels strong or weak. If your sample attracts iron and steel objects, like the nail in the materials kit, you have found a magnetized sample of magnetite, called a lodestone.

pageData.text: Using the results of this activity, refer to in the Mineral Identification section to determine which mineral each sample most likely could be. Record your answers in Data Table 1.

text: Dispose of hydrochloric acid down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solution.
Wipe down the <button class='glossary-text'>streak</button> plates and <button class='glossary-text'>hardness</button>-testing tools. Return the materials to your materials kit.
Sanitize the work space, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A piece of granite

pageData.content: Figure 2. Example of an artificially irradiated gemstone
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A gemstone that has been artificially irradiated to intensify its color

Figure 3: A blue square over a pink circle demonstrates each descriptor of opacity. The top square over a circle is opaque, allowing no light to show through the square; the middle is translucent, with only the shape of the circle visible; and the bottom is transparent, with light showing through and the image of the circle visible.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will obtain and photograph your mineral samples. In activity 1, you will observe the luster and color of the mineral. Then, you will test the streak of the mineral. You will test the streaks in the following order, fingernail on the mineral, penny on the mineral, mineral on glass plate and mineral on streak plate. Once you have a positive streak, do not try the next material, but instead go on to photograph the streak. If it is negative, keep trying the different tests until you get a positive result. If the mineral does not streak the streak plate, record this and go on to observe the cleavage and fracture of the mineral. Next, you will add acid to the mineral and observe for changes. Then, you will test the magnetism of the mineral. Finally, you will classify each mineral according to its properties.

data.title: Adamantine
data.content: Non-metallic luster similar to glass

data.title: Cleavage
data.content: The breakage of a mineral along definite planes that are parallel to the atomic planes of the crystal

data.title: Color
data.content: The aspect of any object that may be described in terms of hue, lightness, and saturation

data.title: Conchoidal
data.content: A fracture that is smooth or curved

data.title: Dull
data.content: A non-metallic luster that has very little shine

data.title: Fibrous
data.content: A fracture that is jagged and sharp

data.title: Fracture
data.content: The breakage of a mineral into irregular planes

data.title: Greasy
data.content: A non-metallic luster that appears as if it is coated with grease or wax

data.title: Hardness
data.content: A mineral's resistance to being scratched

data.title: Heterogeneous
data.content: Of non-uniform composition

data.title: Homogeneous
data.content: Of the same composition throughout

data.title: Irregular
data.content: A fracture that is uneven

data.title: Luster
data.content: The sheen, or gloss, of the mineral surface

data.title: Metallic
data.content: A luster that is similar to that of metal and are reflective

data.title: Nonmetallic
data.content: A luster to does not have a metallic sheen

data.title: Opacity
data.content: A measure of how much light can been seen through a thin slice of a mineral

data.title: Pearly
data.content: A non-metallic luster that displays iridescence

data.title: Resinous
data.content: A non-metallic luster that resembles honey or amber

data.title: Silky
data.content: A non-metallic luster that results in a silky appearance due to parallel fibrous crystals

data.title: Specific gravity
data.content: The weight of a mineral compared to the weight of an equal volume of water

data.title: Splintery
data.content: See "fibrous"

data.title: Streak
data.content: The color of a mineral when it is finely powdered

data.title: Submetallic
data.content: A luster that is nearly opaque but has a metallic sheen

data.title: Tenacity
data.content: A mineral's resistance to breaking, crushing, bending, or tearing

data.title: Vitreous
data.content: See "adamantine"

data.title: Waxy
data.content: See "greasy"
